case_name: Gurcharan Dass Chadha v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Transfer Petition No. 7 of 1965 filed under Section 527 of Criminal Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Transfer Petition No. 7 of 1965.  Under Section 527 of Criminal Procedure Code . R. Bhasin, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Petition seeks transfer of criminal case No. 2 of 1964 State v. Gurcharan Dass Chadha pending in Court of Special Judge, Bharatpur, Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: This is a petition under S. 527 of the Code of Criminal Procedure for the transfer of a criminal case  No. 2 of 1964-state v. Gurcharan Dass Chadha P.S.  which is pending in the Court of the Special Judge, Bharatpur, Rajasthan to another criminal

facts.text: Petitioner is the accused in the case and tried under ss. 120B/161 IPC and S. 5(1)(d) and 5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act.

anchor.surface_text: to another criminal companyrt of equal or superior jurisdiction subordinate to a High Court other than the High Court of Rajasthan. The petitioner is the accused in that case and he is being tried under ss. 120B/161, Indian Penal Code and S. 5 1  a  d  and 52 of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

facts.text: Prosecution sanctioned by Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: prosecution has been sanctioned by the Government of India. In December, 1962, he was serving as Superintendent of Police and was selected to be Commandant of 8th Batallion of Rajasthan Armed Constabulary.

facts.text: In December 1962, petitioner serving as Superintendent of Police and selected to be Commandant of 8th Battalion of Rajasthan Armed Constabulary.

anchor.surface_text: In December, 1962, he was serving as Superintendent of Police and was selected to be Commandant of 8th Batallion of Rajasthan Armed Constabulary. He avers that he took over as Commandant on January 7, 1963 but was placed under suspension the same day

facts.text: Petitioner took over as Commandant on January 7, 1963 but placed under suspension the same day.

anchor.surface_text: He avers that he took over as Commandant on January 7, 1963 but was placed under suspension the same day and a case was registered on January 12, 1963 which has resulted in the present prosecution against him.

facts.text: Case registered on January 12, 1963 leading to present prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: and a case was registered on January 12, 1963 which has resulted in the present prosecution against him. The petitioner apprehends for reasons to be stated presently that he is number likely to get a fair,

facts.text: Petitioner apprehends no fair trial in Rajasthan due to hostility of then Law Minister (also in charge of Home), Additional IG Police Anti-Corruption, DIG Police Ajmer Range.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner apprehends for reasons to be stated presently that he is number likely to get a fair, just and impartial trial in the State of Rajasthan owing to the hostility and influence of the then Law Minister who was also Minister incharge of Home Department of the State, the Additional Inspector General of Police, Anti-Corruption, and the Deputy Inspector General of Police, Ajmer Range, Jaipur.

facts.text: State Government opposed the transfer application and questioned jurisdiction of Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government has opposed the application strenu. ously and has questioned the jurisdiction of this Court to transfer under the powers companyferred on it by s 527 Code of Criminal Procedure a case made over by the Government of the State of Rajasthan for trial to a Special Judge under the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952  Act 46 of 1962 .

facts.text: While petition pending, State served petitioner with notice and charge-sheet for breach of Rule No. 8 of All India Services Conduct Rules, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: While this petition was pending the State Government served the petitioner with a numberice and a charge-sheet to show cause why he should number be proceeded against for breach of Rule No. 8 of the All India Services  Conduct  Rules, 1954,

facts.text: Charge for communicating official documents to counsel R.K. Rastogi, D.P. Gupta and others in writ petition No. 794 of 1964 in Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: because he had companymunicated directly indirectly official documents and information to Government servants other persons to whom he was number authorised to companymunicate such documents information as indicated and detailed in a statement of allegations accompanying the numberice and the charge. The State Government has appended to this charge two appendices giving details of 31 and 16 docu- ments respectively, which were said to have been so companymunicated by the petitioner to his companynsel Messrs. R. K. Rastogi and D. P. Gupta, Advocates of Jodhpur and others named as number-petitioners in a writ petition which he had filed in the High Court of Rajasthan  No. 794 of 1964

facts.text: Writ petition No. 794 of 1964 withdrawn by petitioner on December 23, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: and which he subsequently withdrew on December 23, 1964 before taking action to file the present petition. The numberice, the charge and the statement of allegations accompanying them were signed by Mr. Vishnu Dutt Sharma, Special Secretary to Government.

facts.text: Notice and charge signed by Mr. Vishnu Dutt Sharma, Special Secretary to Government.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice, the charge and the statement of allegations accompanying them were signed by Mr. Vishnu Dutt Sharma, Special Secretary to Government. On receiving this charge, the petitioner moved another petition in this Court for taking action against Mr. Shrama and the Government of Rajasthan for companytempt of this Court.

facts.text: Petitioner filed contempt petition against Mr. Sharma and Government of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: On receiving this charge, the petitioner moved another petition in this Court for taking action against Mr. Shrama and the Government of Rajasthan for companytempt of this Court.

facts.text: State of Rajasthan through Chief Secretary and Mr. Sharma filed replies to contempt petition and later offered unconditional apology.

anchor.surface_text: As a result the State of Rajasthan through the Chief Secretary to the Government and Mr. Sharma separately filed their replies to the second petition and attempted justification. Mr. Sharma abjured knowledge of the companytents of the petition for transfer and denied any malice, ill-will or grudge, pleading good faith. ... The latter was present in Court and expressed regret for what had. happened. We accepted the appology

facts.text: Supreme Court accepted apology and dropped contempt proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: We accepted the appology and do number, therefore,feel called upon to companysider the plea of justification which, in any event, is number a plea heard in bar when companytempt is clear and manifest.

facts.text: Court holds it has jurisdiction under S.527 CrPC to transfer case from one Special Judge to another Special Judge subordinate to another High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the Supreme Court in exercise of its jurisdiction and power under s. 527 of the Code of Criminal Procedure can transfer a case from a special Judge subordinate to one High Court to another special Judge subordinate to another High Court.

facts.text: Court denies transfer on merits as petitioner's apprehension of no fair trial not reasonable.

anchor.surface_text: Applying these principles it may be said that there is a possibility that the petitioner entertains an apprehension that certain persons are hostile to him but his apprehension that he will number receive justice in the State of Rajasthan is number in our opinion reasonable.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Hidayatullah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hidayatullah, J. This is a petition under S. 527 of the Code of Criminal Procedure for the transfer of a criminal case  No. 2 of 1964-state v. Gurcharan Dass Chadha P.S.

facts.text: Petitioner alleges hostility from Home Minister Mr. Mathura Dass Mathur in 1962.

anchor.surface_text: His apprehension is that the case against him is H the result of the machination of two Police Officers and one Mr. Mathura Dass Mathur who was the Home Minister in 1962.He also alleges hostility on the part of the State Government.

facts.text: Petitioner alleges differences with Deputy IG Hanuman Prasad Sharma on three occasions.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the Home Minister the petitioner has given five instances in which he apparently crossed the ministers path and gave him room for annoyance. In regard to the two Police Officers he has averred that the Deputy Inspector General of Police, Ajmer Range  Hanuman Prasad Sharma  and he had some differences on three occasions.

facts.text: State Government downgraded petitioner's post as Commandant.

anchor.surface_text: In relation to the State Government he has alleged that when he was appointed Commandant of the 8th Battallion of Rajasthan Armed Constabulary the State Government down-graded his post, otherwise he would have received a higher starting pay.

facts.text: No allegation against the Special Judge Bharatpur.

anchor.surface_text: Nor does the petitioner allege anything against the special Judge who is trying the case. In this view of the matter we decline to order trans- fer of the case from the special Judge, Bharatpur.

facts.text: Case assigned by State Government to Special Judge under Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: a case made over by the Government of the State of Rajasthan for trial to a Special Judge under the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952  Act 46 of 1962 . In addition, the State Government joins issue on the facts alleged and the merits of the claim for the transfer of the case.

concepts.unlisted_description: Appoints special judges for corruption offenses.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 confers power on the State Government to appoint special Judges for the trial of certain offences. The parts relevant to our purpose read Power to appoint special judges. The State Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint as many special Judges as may be necessary for such area, or areas as may be specified in the notification to try the following offences, namely -  a  an offence punishable under section 161, section 162, section 163, section 164, section 165, or section 165-A of the Indian Penal Code  Act XLV of 1860 , or sub-section  2  of section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947  11 of 1947  Any conspiracy to commit or any attempt to commit or any abetment of any of the offences specified in clause  a .

concepts.interpretation: State Government appoints special judges for specified corruption offenses.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: e read Power to appoint special judges. The State Government may, by numberification in the official Gazette, appoint as many special Judges as may be

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 next provides what cases shall be tried by special Judges.The first two sub-sections read Cases triable by special Judges. Notwithstanding anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898  Act V of 1898  or in any other law the offences specified in sub-section  1  of section 6 shall be triable by special Judges only. Every offence specified in sub- section  1  of section 6 shall be tried by the special Judge for the area within which it was committed, or where there are more special Judges than one for such area, by such one of them as may be specified in this behalf by the State Government.

concepts.interpretation: Offenses triable only by special judge of the area; but does not preclude transfer under CrPC.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: Judges.The first two sub-sections read Cases triable by special Judges. Notwithstanding anything companytained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898

anchor.surface_text: The procedure which the special Judge has to follow is laid down in s. 8  1  and by sub-section  2  of the same section certain powers are conferred on the special Judge. Sub- section  3  then provides Procedure and Powers of Special Judges.  1   2  Save as provided in sub-section  1  or sub-section  2 , the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, shall so far as they are not inconsistent with this Act, apply to the proceedings before a special Judge

anchor.surface_text: The law with regard to transfer of cases is well-settled. A case is transferred if there is a reasonable apprehension on the part of a party to a case that justice will not be done. A petitioner is not required to demonstrate that justice will inevitably fail. He is entitled to a transfer if he shows circumstances from which it can be inferred that he entertains an apprehension and that it is reasonable in the circumstances alleged. It is one of the principles of the administration of justice that justice should not only be done but it should be seen to be done.

concepts.interpretation: Transfer if reasonable apprehension of failure of justice; mere allegation insufficient; applied to deny transfer as apprehension not reasonable.

issues.text: Whether there is a reasonable apprehension on the part of the petitioner that justice will not be done in the trial before the Special Judge, Bharatpur, warranting transfer under Section 527 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: The law with regard to transfer of cases is well-settled. A case is transferred if there is a reasonable apprehension on the part of a party to a case that justice will not be done. A petitioner is not required to demonstrate that justice will inevitably fail. He is entitled to a transfer if he shows circumstances from which it can be inferred that he entertains an apprehension and that it is reasonable in the circumstances alleged.

arguments.claim: Supreme Court lacks jurisdiction under S.527 CrPC to transfer a case made over to a Special Judge under Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952

anchor.surface_text: The State Government has opposed the application strenu. ously and has questioned the jurisdiction of this Court to transfer under the powers conferred on it by s 527 Code of Criminal Procedure a case made over by the Government of the State of Rajasthan for trial to a Special Judge under the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952  Act 46 of 1962 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t is extremely plausible but does number bear close scrutiny. To understand the argument and how it is refuted certain provisions of the Act may be se

arguments.court_reasoning: CLAA s.8(3) preserves CrPC provisions unless inconsistent; no inconsistency with s.527 as territorial jurisdiction yields to transfer powers; precedent in Ramchandra Prasad supports

arguments.claim: Case assigned to special Judge under CLAA cannot be transferred as CLAA is self-contained special law requiring trial by designated special Judge only

anchor.surface_text: It is conceded by the Advocate General that the power to transfer criminal cases as laid down in the section is ordinarily available but he contends that a case assigned by the State Government under the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 to a special Judge cannot be transferred at all because under the terms of that Act, which is a self-contained special law, such a case must be tried by the special Judge designate only.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: a special Judge only but that companydition can be fully met by transferring the case to another special Judge. Indeed section 527 itself companytempl

arguments.court_reasoning: s.7(1) met by transfer to another special Judge; s.7(2) territorial provision not inconsistent with s.527 per s.8(3)

arguments.claim: CLAA s.7(1) and (2) create restrictions: offences triable only by special Judges and by the one for the area of commission

anchor.surface_text: The Advocate General, Rajasthan in opposing the petition relies, principally on the provisions of s. 7 1  and  2  and contends that the two sub-sections create two restrictions which must be read together. The first is that offences specified in s. 6 1  can be tried by special Judges only.

arguments.court_reasoning: Transfer to another special Judge satisfies s.7(1); s.7(2) territorial like CrPC provisions overridden by transfer

arguments.claim: Supreme Court has jurisdiction under s.527 CrPC to transfer case from one Special Judge to another subordinate to different High Court

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the Supreme Court in exercise of its jurisdiction and power under s. 527 of the Code of Criminal Procedure can transfer a case from a special Judge subordinate to one High Court to another special Judge subordinate to another High Court.

arguments.claim: CLAA s.7(1) satisfied by transfer to another special Judge as s.527 contemplates court of equal/superior jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: No doubt sub-section  1  of s. 7 lays down that the trial of an offence specified in sub-section  1  of s. 6 must be by a special Judge only but that condition can be fully met by transferring the case to another special Judge.

arguments.claim: CLAA s.7(2) territorial jurisdiction yields to CrPC transfer provisions as preserved by s.8(3); no inconsistency

anchor.surface_text: The condition that an offence specified in s. 6 2  shall be tried by a special Judge for the area within which it is committed merely specifies which of several special Judges appointed in the State by the State Government shall try it.

arguments.claim: Transfer power under CrPC s.526/527 not barred by territorial provisions analogous to special Judges

holdings.text: the Supreme Court in exercise of its jurisdiction and power under s. 527 of the Code of Criminal Procedure can transfer a case from a special Judge subordinate to one High Court to another special Judge subordinate to another High Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of Criminal Law Amendment Act ss.6-8 with CrPC s.527; s.8(3) preserves CrPC provisions unless inconsistent; no inconsistency as transfer to another special judge meets s.7(1), territorial limit in s.7(2) yields like other territorial provisions; precedent in Ramchandra Prasad v. State of Bihar

holdings.text: No doubt sub-section (1) of s. 7 lays down that the trial of an offence specified in sub-section (1) of s. 6 must be by a special Judge only but that condition can be fully met by transferring the case to another special Judge
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.527 requires transfer to court of equal/superior jurisdiction; special judges exist in other states satisfying s.7(1)

holdings.text: there is no inconsistency between s. 527 of the Code and the second sub-section of s. 7
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.7(2) merely territorial like CrPC provisions for magistrates/sessions judges, overridden by transfer orders under CrPC preserved by CLAA s.8(3); no contradiction as transfer invests jurisdiction

holdings.text: his apprehension that he will not receive justice in the State of Rajasthan is not in our opinion reasonable
holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's allegations relate to past official differences/hostilities; no material showing interference with investigation or trial; no allegation against special judge; mere apprehension insufficient, must be reasonable

holdings.text: we decline to order transfer of the case from the special Judge, Bharatpur
holdings.reasoning_summary: No reasonable apprehension established under settled law on transfers

holdings.text: We accepted the apology and do not, therefore, feel called upon to consider the plea of justification which, in any event, is not a plea heard in bar when contempt is clear and manifest

anchor.surface_text: We accepted the appology and do not, therefore,feel called upon to consider the plea of justification which, in any event, is not a plea heard in bar when contempt is clear and manifest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unconditional apology tendered and accepted; contempt clear but proceedings dropped

holdings.text: Such a course of action is to be deprecated

anchor.surface_text: Such a course of action is to be deprecated and we are glad to note that the Government of Rajasthan and the Secretary concerned have seen the matter in this light and have made amends by proper contrition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge-sheet during pendency created indirect pressure hampering free prosecution of transfer petition, obstructing justice; should wait till proceedings terminate
